UPDATE: Elvis has been improved! Check out "Elvis Skull Resurrected" at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:158022 Thanks to "Cleaned Hollow Skull by ssd" for the mesh of the skull and mandible. I've cleaned up the interior a bit, attached the mandible, and added support and teeth. If anyone can further clean this up, please do. Printable(?) because there are hanging filaments and a great deal of excess plastic on the inside that I haven't been able to lose. The drooping threads vary in quantity and placement depending on the scale. On the upside, the droops are all on the undersides or inside of the print, are easily cleaned up with an X-acto & sandpaper, and don't affect the final appearance.

The .stl file is at the maximum size that fits on my build platform. The other sizes shown were set at 75% and 50% scale in ReplicatorG and take considerably less time to print out. (The full sized Elvis took seven and a half hours to print with zero extra shells and 10% fill.)  
Why Elvis?  
Check out the sneer.

comments.text: I get it now.  There are four separate intersecting objects in the stl file, so skeinforge gets confused as to which surfaces are inside and which are outside.  The brain cavity actually has three surfaces. (Very bad! should never be odd!)
comments.author: ssd

comments.text: That's great! I've tried to clean this up in MeshLab, Netfabb and Rhino with no luck. If you succeed, please post how.
comments.author: ssd

comments.text: I tried to clean it up in meshlab, it just isn't up to it.  Really, I don't think any of these programs can do the whole job, it needs to be merged properly.  Simplest, you could take it into a CSG capable cad program and union the three objects.  I want to try to do better than that by intelligently removing stuff from the center.
comments.author: HPaul

comments.text: Because of the changes to the skull, meshlab didn't extract it cleanly from your drawing.  It kinda pulled out several surfaces together that didn't quite overlap correctly.  So I spent the day stitching the layers together where they didn't join properly.  Meshlab should have been able to do this, but the edge was just too messy for its simplistic hole filling algorithms.  I ended up doing the job mostly by hand in blender, merging points and adding faces to stitch the rough edges.
comments.author: ssd

comments.text: you could probably clean up all the hanging threads by either making all the bottom surfaces horizontal or no shallower than 45 degrees.  This would add material probably, however.

description.text:
Heres a little something I knocked up as a house warming gift for a friend.
Its based on a Dean Dimebag Razerback rebel. Its made in 3 sections.
-headstock
-neck
-body Each section is made from 2 layers of 3mm acrylic.
Between the 2 layers of acrylic is a sheet of card I lasered and painted both sides black. The etching is done on the back side of the front peice of acrylic.
This gives a better finish.
The whole thing is bolted together with 5mm bolts. Slip in your favorite Dime pic and your done!
Finished guitar is 900mm tall but you could just scale it up and go full size. anyway enjoy!

Etch it,
cut it,
cut your card,
paint your card,
print your pic, assemble! light candle!!

MakerBot

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter
These are for little kids that have nothing to do. I do not have a 3D printer to test print this.

Project: Building blocks Objective: To give bored little kids something to do
Audiences: Little kids in preschool
Preparation: A creative mind
Steps: 3D print, multiply in your preferred slicer if needed, then use. It is recommended to sand down the edges and corners.
Results: Kids busy

https://youtu.be/vWFyRtlEq_g This is derived from the grabcab model:
https://grabcad.com/library/3d-printable-v8-engine-desk-toy-1 I changed the pistons so their gudgeon pins are the full width, the connecting rods are now hook snap fit, the crankshaft is one piece, and added a handle to crank the engine over. 1) Just print:
EngineBlock.stl 1pc
CrankShaft.stl 1pc (Print the crankshaft on its end with support. Simplify3D recommended)
PistonArm.stl 8pcs
PistonHead.stl 8pcs
Handle 1pc
CrankshaftClamp 2pcs 2)Drill 4 holes in Engine block for securing the 'Crankshaftclamp'
3)snap 'PistonArm's to the piston heads
4)snap 'PistonArm's to the crankshaft (make sure the hook is hidden)
5)tap the end of the crankshaft M4x0.7mm
6)use 3x M4 flat washers as spacers between the crankshaft end and the handle
7)secure the handle to the crank shaft with an 10mm long M4x0.7mm socket cap screw
8)drop the assembled crankshaft into the engine block
9)Screw on the clamps with self tapping screws
10)(optional) using silicone based oil -> lubricate the cylinder walls, piston wrist, and crankshaft bearing surfaces
11) turn the handle manually or use an electric screwdriver for the best effect. http://www.ordsolutions.com
https://www.facebook.com/OrdSolutionsInc
https://twitter.com/ordsolutions

description.text: I designed this Skyrim key chain using Autodesk Inventor. I printed it with ABS filament using my robotics team's XYZ da Vinci 1.0 printer on the "excellent" quality setting, slow print speed, 0.1mm layer height, and 90%(solid) infill density. I scaled the x-axis to be 1 inch(25.4 mm). Post-Processing included sanding it with 120 grit and 220 grit sandpaper, cleaning up all the edges using an X-ACTO knife, and treating it with an acetone vapor bath.

Replaces the plastic part that holds the metal clamp piece which holds up the passenger front right window. Fits my 1999 Volkswagen Passat, and should fit other B5 and B5.5 types as well (1996-2005).

There are two of these in the door. Each one is mounted reversed of the other one. The driver side is similar, and if someone is interested I can make that one as well.
I recommend some sort of machining device to remote strands and make sure holes are the proper size (I printed using PLA).
I also used some lithium grease to help it slide more easily.

title: Adjustable GPU Support Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this thing because I have a rather large graphics card that sags and I'm always worried I'm going to damage something when I transport my computer. This GPU bracket is completely adjustable to work with any GPU that has a heatsink cover, and should work with any case that has recessed expansion slots. It attaches via the existing expansion slots in your case. Extra materials include 5 small screws, and 2 small washers or a chain link, which is what I used. I printed this part with ABS filament on a XYZ da Vinci 1.0 printer. The back_plate should be printed with a relatively high infill density as there will be a lot of stress on that part. I printed all the other parts at 10% infill density. Note:
-When I was first putting the screws in and creating the threads, the friction caused the wall in one of the holes to break. I recommend putting a bit of acetone in the holes to soften up the plastic when first making the threads.
-Take the care not to over tighten the adjustable slider, because on my first try I tightened it too much, causing the back plate to snap in two.

This a lollipop tree that allows you to fill it with lollipops (I used dum dums). They spiral up the tree and the angle of the lollipop gradually changes to more vertical higher up the tree.
The design can be customized. The tree is fundamentally a cone. You can set the radius of the base of the cone, the height of the cone and the number of times the lollipops will go around the cone as they spiral up. You can also customize it for the type of lollipop you want to put in it by setting the radius of the stick, the "height" of stick to be embedded into the cone and the amount of separation between sticks.
The bottom-most holes are not usable since they do not make full circles. Initially I was going to change the code to eliminate these holes altogether, but I like the look they contribute to the spiral.

I noticed a startling lack of small projectiles in my office. I also noticed an abundance of 20mm calibration cubes. Solution: Desktop Tebuchet. Video Demo: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kW5KLmR86kk

Print sled.stl and frame3.stl twice. Don't print trebuchetassembled.stl. Print 1 of everything else. Assembly is pretty easy, if you need help download the assembled sketchup file. The supports will have to be glued into the bases. That's the only place where my print required glue. The 45mm x 3mm bolt is the axle for the counterweight basket. You'll also have to make a sling. I used duct tape and some cotton string (see image.) When the sling is hanging from the arm, the bottom of the sling should be at the main axle. Use a drill to add a small hole (I used 1/16") to the top of the throw arm, go through the hole for attaching the sling and into the other side a bit. About 1/4". Cut a straight section of a paperclip and insert it into the hole, bend it back (away from the pieces printed in frame2.stl) to about a 45 degree angle. This pin controls when your sling will let the projectile loose, straighten it up a bit if it's releasing too late, bend it more if too soon. Add counterweight to the basket, the ratio of counterweight to projectile mentioned on sites that know about such things is between 75:1 and 100:1. I use a bunch of brass keys. It's all really "fiddly" for a bit, but once you get your weights, sling, and pin adjusted properly it works pretty well. For more info on making adjustments see:
http://members.localnet.com/~lorilee35/tuning.html
http://thehurl.wikidot.com/tuning Have fun and don't put your eye out.

To get around the problem, I had to set Support2.stl  to  -1 xyz scale to mirror it.

author: Prop_er

title: Inductive proximity z-probe adapter. Works with glass cover.

description.text:
Note: this adapter will work for detachable probes only or as temporary attachment for calibration. You can't just add this adapter to permanently mounted probe that only 2-3 mm higher than nozzle. My aluminum Kossel bed is not so flat, so I covered it with 3mm glass. Much better, but inductive probe stopped working. Here is the adapter I made. You will need a #14 0.08" (2mm) nail and very light spring (I used one from this kit http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-Spring-Assortment-Kit-84-Pack-15642/202045461). Actually, it works even without spring because of the weight of nail/tip. You can replace the spring with thin U-shaped piece of plastic (PET bottle, etc). This modification doesn't affect the sensitivity and precision. Don't forget to adjust the z-probe height in firmware. I had to make one more :) How it works: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=83hY3M8QLtg
Animated probe video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C8dT_2mZWXk Printed with PLA 180C, 044mm nozzle
  • 0.2mm height
  • 0.5mm manually set width
  • 30 mm/s with slicer cooling enabled
  • better to print together for optimal cooling

comments.text: an a pen-clicker mechanism be somehow incorporated so that at the end of the probe cycle the Z is more aggressively engaged to activate a cam just like the case of the classic and ubiquitous pen. comments.author: mbthor

comments.text: Interesting idea, but I think that clicker mechanism will add an additional error affecting the reliability of whole assembly. Every segment of clicker must have equal height and all parts must have zero backlash.
comments.author: mbthor

comments.text: I don't think it will introduce any additional error, because the probe will trigger always before hitting the critical point where the pen-clicker would retract it. So it will basically be a spring-based triggering until the force is high enough to click the mechanism ... everything that happens after this clicker activation YES it's unreliable to measuring but this will happen when the actual measuring is done.

description.text:
My pet budgie Rodger needed something to stand on at the front of his cage door - as its where he waits for me, until I put my hand out, for him to join me on my travels. Simply slots into the front of the cage - nothing else required! I made two versions:
Small - Contains 2x 5mm small bars and 1x 10mm bar at the front
Large - Contains 2x 10mm bars EDIT: ADDED STRONGER VERSION (filename v2 - stronger) AS PART OF THE MOUNTING SECTION BROKE OFF ON MINE AFTER TIME I found Rodger has trouble standing on the smaller barred version as the gaps between the bars are small. I redesigned to only 2 larger bars with larger gaps and he is much happier with that. :) Size is 87mm wide and sits 60mm long outside the door Please Post your Makes!

Super cool

This is a model the so called "20mm Gantry plate" for the OpenRail as made by OpenBuilds (it really is 80x80mm). I needed to reference this plate in one of my designs, and hoped/expected to find this in the OpenRails part files from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24886 I could not find it there, so I modeled it up quickly. The closest I could get to a reference file model that's not Solidworks was IGES and STL, so that's what's been uploaded ;) The dimensions are really simple. Holes are 5mm diameter, except the 7mm holes for eccentric spacers. Plate is 80x80mm outer, holes are located on centerlines and 22.5mm off center for the outer hole set, the inner hole set is at 10mm offset of center. The OpenRail system was created by Mark and Trish Carew of http://www.OpenBuilds.com

A hangable 3D scanner based on the kinect, arduino, and a stepper motor.
Not working yet, but figured I'd put it up so I could get critiques and suggestions as I work.
The code base is currently in progress, will be borrowing heavily from Kyle McDonald's work for Makerbot, of course. Am sketching it up at the moment, unsure whether I want to do it in Java (very familiar) or Cpp through OF.
v0.2 (files up, not tested or 100%) Defined solution for hub. 4 piece design with bearings.
v0.15 Physical testing and modification of outerJoint and innerJoint. These include adding radial support screws, modified teeth, and refined build methods. The failed code is retained in the build methods with explanation, just for the hell of it.
v0.1 Framework of object and base line openSCAD file. Only parts printed/tested so far are arm joints.

Modify settings in openscad as needed.
Export all export-ready modules.
Attach motor and arduino, upload code. Hang over object. Connect Computer (I have a plan for routing the cables, but is still in sketchbook) Scan. Print.

comments.text: Regarding a counterweight, why not weigh the kinect + the portion of the arm that does not get longer, and make a counterweight 4 times as heavy. Hand that counterweight on an arm that is controlled by the same gear mechanism as the extending arm, but with a 4 times reduction. The kinect arm is extended on the side of the gear that has 40 teeth, and the counterweight is on the side that has 10 teeth...

description.text:
This is a Bixler V1.1 mount for the PIXHAWK/PX4 autopilot and all its accessories, there is room enough for the autopilot, rc radio, GPS, fpv camera etc. The assembly is pretty straight forward, you can help yourself with the pictures.
When assembled it is recommended to superglue everything together, you don't want it disassemble in mid-air. The holes in the bottom plate are for the PX4, if you want to install the PIXHAWK or any other autopilot you could use double sided tape.

Secure it to the Bixler You suppose to secure the whole thing to the Bixler using a couple of rubberbands by using the spaces in the middle plate, but that doesn't work that well and i fear that it will snap in the air so i just put the rubberband around the whole thing, two of them, one in the back and one in the front, that way it was strongly secure.

Remix fron a 2D file I found this post (http://diydrones.com/profiles/blogs/px4-bixler-chassis) in th diydrones forum and there were all the 2D designs for cut them in a laser cut, so i just add the 3rd dimension and this was the result.

Powiększone pliki do obudowy mendel90, tak aby pasowały do ramy z MDFu (wersja syntetycznego http://www.byq3d.eu/index.php?id_product=23&controller=product&id_lang=7 ). Większość plików jest taka sama jak w oryginalne czyli:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755654 Enlarged files to the housing mendel90 so that they fit into the frame with MDF (ver syntetycznego http://www.byq3d.eu/index.php?id_product=23&controller=product&id_lang=7 ). Most of the files is the same as the original that is:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755654 [edit]
Wkradł się mały błąd. Zamiast pliku top_front_V1_1_2_z.stl powinien być top_front_V1_1_3_z.stl (środek frontu). Przepraszam za moją pomyłkę. Przed wydrukiem polecam również wszystkim dokładny pomiar ramy. He crept a little mistake. Instead top_front_V1_1_2_z.stl file should be top_front_V1_1_3_z.stl (center front). I am sorry for my mistake. Before printing, also I recommend all accurate measurement of frame. top_guide_1_z.stl - boczny panel od strony czoła drukarki
top_guide_3_z.stl - boczny panel od strony czoła drukarki
top_front_V1_1_3_z.stl - środkowy panel od frontu top_guide_1_z.stl - side panel from the front of the printer
top_guide_3_z.stl - side panel from the front of the printer
top_front_V1_1_3_z.stl - middle panel from the front

author: Zpeagler

title: Minimalist Dial Indicator Holder for MendelMax 2 MM2

description.text:
This thing is not really needed. I found later the tab on the back of the indicator can be rotated, and mount the tab to the edge of the carriage. This is a minimalist indicator holder for MendelMax 2. It assumes the dial indicator has a 9.5mm fixed shank below the dial. It can be easily drilled to 10mm without compromising the structure, maybe more. It mounts to the X carriage the same way the MaxStruder mounts, so it should not interfere with any kind of fan mounts that are compatible with the MaxStruder. The indicator can be rotated for reading from any side.
This holder doesn't require any additional hardware beyond the dial indicator and the screws already used to mount the extruder.
The mounting holes are 80mm apart. I plan to make a change so it has 50mm spaced holes too, which is a more common RepRap extruder mount hole pattern.
This should be rigid, but it doesn't really need much. Two shells plus your preferred infill percentage and preferred layer height should be fine.

His case has been called one of the worst miscarriages in US Justice Check out his art work online and learn more about his case. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leonard_Peltier

remixed_from.title: Auryn Medallion from The NeverEnding Story

description.text: This is just a little badge that I made from the Auryn. It's going on top of our christmas tree.

There are many sources of aluminum clamps for 12mm CF tubing, but the hole spacing is usually too large for 16mm X 19mm motor mounting patterns, so you can't use them as the only method of motor mounting. Also, since the motor bodies are tapped aluminum, I feel more comfortable if all 4 motor screws are inserted - something you can't do if you simply screw the motor to the clamp.  This adaptor fits between the motor and the  tubing clamp.  It is made for M3 capscrews, and all the screw heads are recessed.  This design is for motors with bodies no larger than 30mm.
Dedicated to S6 DSE students in Hong Kong

Camera is recessed back so the lens does not protrude far beyond the front pillars. If / when a crash happens, this will reduce the chance of any broken lenses. It also reduces the amount of debris the props fling onto the lens as well. 
Prints in two pieces at 20% infill.

description.text:
Remixed version of a lovely lamp bra. The problem with original models is that without supports the angle is close to 45 degrees and therefore material tempts to slid.
The remix is done by stretching vertically the original model and cutting the bottom part to fit into my 140 height limit of Flashforge 3D Dreamer. I tried to use myself AutoCAD Shapeshifter (http://www.123dapp.com/sandbox) but I was not able to get anything similar to what you did in terms of shape and smoothness of the original lamp.
The yellow lamp is exact model. The blue one is squeezed to 100x100 but the print quality is suddenly decreasing.

author: EvilTeach

description.text:
A holder to allow an XBee on a Ciseco XBBO breakout board to be mounted on a standard Arduino prototyping shield.  
I needed a convenient way to mount an XBee on a shield in a current project, using the SoftwareSerial library with pins D6 and D7 in order to keep Tx and Rx free. Although some of the commercial XBee shields can be configured this way they almost all use the ISP header, which wasn't possible with my current project. Hence this holder to allow the breakout to be fitted to a plain prototyping shield.

The holder was printed raftless with layers=3 and infill=0.2 (though there's very little solid volume). The clips may be quite fragile - brushing them with acetone makes them considerably stronger.  The STL file contains a 'blob' which I find helpful to get the extruder primed before starting the main print.  
Cut a spare long-legged header down to 5 pins and bend the legs at 90 degrees - this will be the connection to the XBee breakout board. Solder the link wires to the connecting holes on the prototyping shield near the main Arduino headers and route them carefully to the holes where the XBee header will fit. Be sure the connections are correct!  Thread the stripped ends through the holes but don't solder them yet. Pop the legs of the 5-pin header though the slot in the holder and check that you can fit it flush against the shield and that the legs of the header will fit though the holes with the link wires. Once it fits OK, apply some adhesive (clear general purpose glue should be fine) and hold it firmly in place until the glue dries. Then slip the connector on the XBee breakout board into the header and clip the board into the holder. With everything held firmly in place, solder the header and link wires to the prototyping board.  
Finally, recheck your wiring, then fit the XBee and away you go!

comments.author: Danydan

description.text:
Replaces the mechanical switch Z endstop - This endstop is super critical to get good bed adhesion. I feel that the original mechanical switch one was not as repeatable as this optical one is. You can find the optical switch on Ebay, search for "Slot Type Optical Coupling" they are around $1.5 each. The pinout is usually printed on the back, DO is the digital out which you connect to the original switch signal lead, AO is analog out that you can leave unconnected. I bent the header pins straight up so I could get it closer to the top plate, they were at 90deg. The makergear M2 (at least my version) had an LED indicator mounted next to the switch, this LED had its Cathode (-) to one side of the switch (connect this lead to DO), and its Anode (+) side connected to an extra wire that just goes back to VCC on the PCB(connect this lead to + on optical switch). The common ground from the switch and LED is then connected to the optical switch GND. - Yours could be wired differently though - check with a multimeter before hooking up. Optical endstop - must recompile Marlin firmware to invert the Z end stop sensor signal - or invert the signal with a NOT gate if you don't like recompiling things.. For Marlin firmware the relevant setting is:
"const bool Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false; // set to true to invert the logic of the endstop." For best results use this along with my constant nut tension device:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:973075/ Youtube video covering my various Makergear M2 Mods:
https://youtu.be/jD6ZTcCd0j8 By - http://www.easybotics.com/
And - http://hilo90mhz.com/

remixed_from.author: invent0r
remixed_from.title: E3D Chimera Cyclope To Prusa i3 Rework Mount

title: Prusa I3 Rework Chimera mount with BLTouch platform

description.text:
Just finished model creation (2015-12-12), will print tomorrow and test fit Chimera and BLTouch sensor. This model is built using measurements taken from invent0r's STL file. The complete model is a fresh build in 123D Design using those measurements as well as design doc specs from Charles Lee and the BLTouch team. Edit(2015-12-14) Printed it out yesterday and parts fit is pretty good. The usual touch up of holes with a drill, but hex openings are perfect for the 4mm nuts. BLTouch pin is inline with the two extrusion nozzles and the retracted pin is between 2.5 and 3mm above the nozzles. Time will tell if that is the correct position, but if anything it will need to be shimmed down with washers I'm guessing. Could really use a print cooling fan that mounts to this in some fashion..... Edit(2015-12-14) Uploaded new version without text labels but including mount points for print cooling fans. I'm going to leverage the fan ducts and mounting arms from Thingy #540716. I will print it tomorrow and check fit and function. Edit(2015-12-15) Printed out the new version with fan mounts and it looks like it is going to work well. Now for the dreaded tear down and conversion from stock to Chimera.....hopefully it will be worth the effort. Edit(2015-12-21) Tear down completed over the weekend and all parts fit perfectly. Only issue is that the standard Pi3 Rework x-axis endpoint switch location is not being hit. I ended up gluing on a piece of scrap print so that it would hit the switch. Today I added the x-axis endpoint trigger "finger" to the design and reprinted using the printer with the previous mount version. I will replace the mount with the new version tonight if I get a chance. In regards to the BLTouch sensor and mount, it's perfect lines up with no y-axis offset, 19mm x-axis offset, and -.48mm z-axis offset. Took me a few tries to get everything set correctly, but now it's smooth as silk and I no longer need to worry about getting the bed 100% level manually, though I will plan to check it from time to time and give it a rough manual leveling if necessary mainly to deal with the chimera requiring a fairly level bed so both nozzles are at the same relative height from the bed.
I will try to take some real pictures of the part and perhaps a quick vid of it in action. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KbuQ6rgdl1c&feature=youtu.be)

description.text:
This is a Remix of NeverDun's Half Stepper Fan mount. I wanted a simpler solution for my CTC Dual Printer so I simplified it and made it fit. There are 2 fan covers also so both fans will match. I have done over 20 prints so far with no fails.
Remove the left Stepper Motor assemby and the wiring from the mother board to be safe. Put the new Fan Stepper into place and insert the Nozzle blower from the bottom. (I used a drop of super glue on each side to make sure it doesnt fall off, but it will snap into place.)
Place the new fan on the Top and screw it in. The old fan screws will work but I had to drill out the fan holes a tad bit to tap them in place. The holes to hold the stepper fan assembly will work without drilling them out and you can use the old bolts to mount it.
I simply ran my fans in Parallel with no problems thus far, but you can add a mosfet on the bottom of the board if you wish to control it.

description.text:
I have tried a few hoppers for my Filastruder and I found a very good one for vertical mounting is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:455026 . I just needed to make a few modifications as follows: Hopper shoot:
I wanted to use an empty coke bottle so I can see all the pellets inside. I changed the feeding tube with a gradual shape change into a suitable mounting - the bottle end sticks in there tight enough. It is made for a 1.25L coke bottle but you might try others.
Also, I merged the Lower Part A and the Hopper Shoot from the original design I found that the Lower Part A was very weak at the thin edges from the feeding cavity. Joining the two parts fixed that.
I also cut out a little of the inside guide that was just a bit long for the hole in my pipe. Lower Part B:
I strengthened the part - just gave it some more thickness. Shoot Door:
I really liked the door in the original design - being able to dump all the pellets in the shoot was quite useful. BUT... overnight whilst extruding some filament I had an unfortunate door moment. The pellets inside had obviously worked their way into an undesirable position due to the movement of the auger... AND... WELL... I'm still getting pellets out of the carpet. So, I modified the door with a little channel that can accommodate that marvel of modern engineering - a rubber band. Keeps the pellets where they need to be. Enjoy! EDIT 14/12/2015: Added photo of black hopper mounted on Filastruder.
EDIT 24/1/2016: Added lid for 1.25L bottle where bottom is cut off.
Solidworks - imported STL files, added bits, removed bits, exported to STL

description.text:
This is used to organize wires in a storage container that has removable dividers. The end result is a way to easily store wires in a container, and find what you need when you need it.
  • Six deep wells, allowing you to store six different types of wires in one divider
  • Optional 5-wells on opposite side
  • Angled entry to guide the wire into the well
  • Narrow entry/exit prevents wires from bending out
  • Deep wells to maximize number of wires that can be held
  • Flexible design with a spring-like feel that allows entry point to be very narrow

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

n/a

Notes: A fast print may result in a print that is too thin. There is a very good chance that you will need to edit the file to fit in your storage container. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ik4jglYJsOs

Problem The problem is that I often have a mess of wires after I am done prototyping. They take up a lot of space. The next time that I start using the wires, I am spending time hunting for wires in the mess. Goals
  • Easy to visually find a specific wire
    1. Color
    2. Size
    3. End type (male/female)
  • Easy to put wires away
  • Easy to take 1 wire at a time
  • Can transport wires effortlessly (1 hand)
  • Hold wire in place
    • Prototyping I first started with cardboard and a pair of scissors. The prototype showed that it would be a nice solution, but the material wasn't up to par. It's difficult to cut with precision and avoid compromising the structure. Plastic would have to do. I could cut the existing dividers, but it would be difficult, ugly and ruin the possibility of reusing the box for something else later. I took measurements and started designing a model. The first print was too tight. Another was too thin, and so on. As I started printing off more prototypes, I was able to used them and see how the wires reacted to them. I found that the curved ones were bending out of place, so I created a bottle neck to prevent them from cumming out on their own. Results I am able to store my wires easily. I can carry the container and put it on a shelf out of the way.

An iterative speed test for checking for skipped steps and maxing out the possible speeds of a delta printer.

Printer:

Mini-kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

0%

Notes: Set to 0% infill, 1 top and 1 bottom layer. The design is meant to be used with NO EXTRUDE MODE. I am sure this model would put plastic down, but it's really designed just for the sake of testing the maximum possible speeds of a printer. It does this by iterating between long and progressively shorter straight movements with more and more jerky movement in between. The metrics to test are Acceleration, jerk, and print speed in that order.
Start by making increasing acceleration 500-1000 until you either notice no change, or your printer begins skipping steps. If it skips steps, reduce by 10%. Increase jerk likewise. After reaching maximum Jerk and Acceleration, increase the print/movement speed via your slicer. Reduce Acceleration and jerk by 50% before beginning. Work your way up to maximum for the new speed.

description.text:
Replaces the rather crappy original (a screw and a washer - at least that's how mine came)
There are 2 versions - the Mk6 has extra teeth on the bottom for extra grip !
I also put a drop or 2 of Supaglue on to stop any slippage - the original design was, IMHO, very prone to stretch then break at the 3mm attachment hole
I usually print at least 2 - makes the top of the print a lot firmer - hardly any filament ooze with 2
It may also be useful on other 3D printers with a similar belt system.

title: Puzzle-Together Laptop Stand (Formerly "Infinitely Wide Laptop Stand")

description.text: This space-saving laptop stand is designed to be printed in sections and fitted together like a puzzle -- giving you the ability to make your laptop stand multiple colors, so you can represent your school, company, service organization, or a cause that's important to you! This compact stand lifts your laptop up and over your external keyboard, letting you use both in tight spaces. This model has a smaller build size than the original design (see "Remixed From"), which protects against the higher failure rate inherent in larger prints, and also allows you to print a laptop stand of any width on a Makerbot Replicator 2 or 2X! Current status of this work-in-progress: Pieces fit together snugly and securely into working laptop stands! Currently tweaking print settings to try to get smooth curves on the puzzle piece part, which often come out with rumpled edges. This is purely aesthetic, though.

MakerBot Replicator 2X

title: Sparkfun Shadow Chassis Side Strut & Mounts

description.text: Sparkfun sells a chassis for robots call the "Shadow" (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13301). It is a great chassis for building beginner robots. It snaps together, which is great, but unfortunately if you are not too careful, the parts can break when unsnapping. In particular, I broke the side strut that connects the top and bottom deck of the chassis. So, I created a replacement part. In addition, Sparkfun sells a sensor called the VL6180 ToF sensor (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/12785). I wanted it mounted on the front of my robot, but there was no easy way to do this using the existing side struts. I originally designed a part (by hand at first, then in a CAD program) that would mount onto the existing side struts, but then figured why not go all the way and design a replacement side strut that could mount the VL6180 sensor instead. So, there are currently two part files: sparkfun_shadow_side_strut.stl - This is a replacement for the side strut that comes with Shadow chassis kit. It is not the same design, but it is the same height with the same flanges for snapping into the top and bottom plates. sparkfun_shadow_side_strut_vl6180_mount.stl - This is the replacement side strut, but now with some added portion to allow the mounting of the VL6180 ToF sensor. There should be plenty of space to mount the sensor with the 90 degree header connectors and connect the connectors to the header.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

fine

I used the online CAD software OnShape (www.onshape.com) to design a replacement part, then I generated various prototypes until I got the measurements to match the original side struts that come with Shadow chassis kit.

author: mwomack

description.text:
Based on the original HBP Blower design I slightly modified this part due to some warping I experienced.
My goal was to raise the blower by a few mm's to give a little more clearance to the bed and to change the angle or remove the curve at the bottom of the blower whilst keeping the original design.
The screw holder was replaced with a longer rectangular holder and a large rectangular opening was added in order for the part to be positioned higher or lower.
All credit for the original design goes to the BEEVERYCREATIVE TEAM

MUHAHAHAHA!!!!       That's what I felt like while printing my army of glowing red skulls all lined up in formation.    The Glowing Red skull army invaded my Christmas tree and the Glowing Blue Skulls are defending it valiantly! Awesome site to behold!
I used the Pencil topper idea and filled in the bottom so it would print super easy now.
Then I made a hole in the back of the head, angled so you can slide it right onto regular christmas light bulbs.
I could fit 48 on my print bed and I made two batches a Translucent Red and a Translucent Blue.  See pictures.

title: VTOL motor tilt mechanism
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple tilt mechanism that i designed for a VTOL aircraft that I am building. This design uses a standard 40g servo. I used the HXT5010.
additionally it uses a 685 bearing. I know most here would consider it a non-standard bearing. But that is the one used as the main shaft bearing for a 450 size helicopter and I had quite a few spare. Please feel free to customize or better even, draw the parts in OpenScad.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 rework

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: rotate the motor mount file(Motor.STL) by 180degrees before slicing. The bearing center is designed like a keyed shaft so that it can be printed vertically. This makes the part, lot stronger. I have found this method to generate a lot stronger shaft parts.
The key idea is to print the length of the shaft in every layer. Flattening it out on one edge helps in printing with out support.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/KpUCQDUlLLI" ></iframe>

title: SNAILZ... Note holders for people who are slow to get things done!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
'SNAILZ' is a simple fun print that holds notes and cards in the curved slots in its shell. They're for holding notes reminding you of things to do, as a business card holder or even in the kitchen to hold recipes. 
The slightly curved slots in the shell makes paper / card inserted curve slightly so it stays rigid enough to stand up and stay in place. There are 5 deep slots in total.  . 
Very simple prints that need no support, are practical and make a great gift... particularly well suited for people who have a habit of being slow to get things done!
...and please post pictures of your SNAILZ!
Please refer to the print settings and images for additional information. 
Note: If you like this check out all my other fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

3 Shells / 30% recommended

Notes: Easy print... no support should be necessary regardless of the overhangs. The angles applied should still print well in PLA without support.

remixed_from.author: ch1t0
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 parts (extruder and carriage, x-end vertical, and z-top stabilizers)

description.text:
The Prusa i3 Rework evolve, you will find this new revision 1.5 here. This version of the Prusa Mendel iteration 3 rev 1.0 is based on the EiNSTeiN VARIANT (M10 threaded rods instead of M8).
Changelog:
04/11/2013 : 1.75mm extruder version added
We changed some features :
  • Extruder upgrade :support J-Head
  • New cooling fan duct for J-Head
  • Y Idler with a tensioner system.
  • X End Idler with endstop holder.
  • Upgrade X End Idler in order to support 624 bearing.
  • Y Motor with endstop holder.
  • Addition of Z Endstop Holder in situ.
    Enjoy !
Assembly instructions are available here : English and French.
Prusa i3 kit will be available on sale soon on Reprap-France.com.

Based on a scanned Elephant Coat Hanger I did, as the original one (http://www.nadjacarlotti.com/pateres-en-porcelaine/ BTW: not existing anymore) is in a very fragile material I wanted to be sure to be able to renew it.
The resolution is not perfect, probably the scan I did was not as close as it has to be to the original object. I've made again some details via sculptris, and add the hole behind to fix it with a bolt on the wall via meshmixer (both software are AMAZING !).
Nevertheless it's great to add more in my house to handle my child coats ! in summary, the worflow is:
  • scan with 123D catch
  • import only the .obj without the mapping (avoid memory issues) in meshmixer to isolate the elephant from the rest of the scene, and add the hole behind
  • import the isolated elephant to sculptris (.obj) and add any details
  • export again to meshmixer and prepare the stl for printing
  • print in PLA with support needed beyond 40°

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

35

Notes: print in PLA with support made beyond 40°
wall 1,6mm (can be more in case of to increase rigidity of the trumk).

description.text: This is a new design by GHT for experimenting with 3D printing. This simple cube has tubes running through the walls to have water fill them. Then, the device is placed in the freezer to freeze the water. After frozen, just place any object in the compartment of the device and your fridge is now running!
The device was designed in Inventor Fusion for concise measurements and design.

comments.text: Keep in mind that there are tubes vertically and horizontally. Horizontal ones are in the base of the model.

comments.text: Not to sound like a dick... but water expands when it is frozen.  And, from the design, looks like it would break the plastic apart.  Just say'n.

comments.text: I thought of that when I built it but I figure'd I'd test it. Surprisingly, thanks to the way the tubes are setup, the ice expands upwards. Don't fill the tubes to the top, almost all the way though. I also recommend printing in a medium or thick plastic. Mine works perfectly :)

title: Easy mount for Hobbyking Turnigy FPV200 Set and V700 mini camera

description.text: This is a FPV fixing Thing, You just take "Turnigy FPV200 Set w/LT200 5.8GHz 200mW FPV A/V Micro Transmitter and V700 Mini Camera" from Hobbyking and print the holder, so you are able to put everything inside and it's pretty well fixed. So you can move it from model to model. If you have a small battery it's even self powered and moving is even easier. Everything fits pretty well. Add some double sided tape or move some nails in the wholes to fix it in your foamie.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3V

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

15

Notes: I printed it with 0.25 layer high and with no support if you cool your extruder. I used 15% infill and the camera fits in exactly you have to turn it a Little bit so the screw goes through. There is as well a small hook to attach a zip tie where you can fix the cables in between.

If you add a small battery it's pretty moveable and you can just put it on every RC vehicle you have because it's self powered, so just take it away and move it to another vehicle and enjoy FPV on that as well.
